title: Korea's Economic Growth Could Fall Below Key 2% Level This Year
text:
Korea's economy grew by just 0.4 percent during the third quarter of this year, making it unlikely that this year's annual growth target of 2 percent will be reached.

The government has resorted to intensive pump-priming measures to resuscitate the sputtering economy, but that was probably not enough to stimulate dormant corporate investments and private spending.

The Bank of Korea said Thursday that third-quarter GDP growth stood at just 0.4 percent, falling short of economists' forecasts of 0.5 to 0.6 percent.

The contributions to GDP growth of corporate investments and private consumption have declined for five straight quarters, a worse record than in the immediate aftermath of the global financial crisis, when their contributions fell for four consecutive quarters, from the fourth quarter of 2008 to the third quarter of 2009.

The government initially forecast Korea's economy would grow between 2.4 to 2.5 percent this year, but recently lowered that to 2 to 2.1 percent. But even that target now appears optimistic. The country has posted less than 2 percent growth four times since 1954 -- in 1956 (0.7 percent) due to a lean harvest; in 1980 (-1.7) due to the second Middle East oil crisis; in 1998 (-5.5 percent) due to the Asian financial crisis; and in 2009 (0.8 percent) due to the global financial crisis.

More troubling is that the psychologically important 2-percent level may be breached this year, without any major economic shock.

Sung Tae-yoon at Yonsei University said, "Since the economy grew 3.2 percent in 2017, if the rate falls to below 2 percent in just over two years, it is tantamount to a 40 percent decline in earnings terms."

Sung added, "Government spending is necessary to stimulate private-sector consumption and investments, but fiscal spending right now is mostly geared toward welfare and is not playing a huge role in bolstering potential growth."
description: Korea's Economic Growth Could Fall Below Key 2% Level This Year
